discussion.note: 2014-04-13 Beman: skip_permissions_denied not being used is a symptom of a more serious problem; two directory_itorator constructors are missing directory_options arguments and a description of how they are used. Proposed wording provided.
17 Jun 2014 LWG requests two signatures rather than one with default argument. Beman updates wording.

blockquote.p: Effects: For the directory that p resolves to, constructs an iterator for the first element in a sequence of directory_entry elements representing the files in the directory, if any; otherwise the end iterator.

p.ins: However, if options & directory_options::skip_permissions_denied != directory_options::none and construction encounters an error indicating that permission to access p is denied, constructs the end iterator and does not report an error.

blockquote.p: Effects: Constructs a iterator representing the first entry in the directory p resolves to, if any; otherwise, the end iterator.

p.ins: However, if options & directory_options::skip_permissions_denied != directory_options::none and construction encounters an error indicating that permission to access p is denied, constructs the end iterator and does not report an error.

blockquote.p: Effects: As specified by C++11 § 24.1.1 Input iterators, except that:

ul.li: If there are no more entries at this depth, then if depth()!= 0 iteration over the parent directory resumes; otherwise *this = recursive_directory_iterator() .

Otherwise if recursion_pending() && is_directory(this->status()) && (!is_symlink(this->symlink_status()) || (options() & directory_options::follow_directory_symlink) != 0 directory_options::none) then either directory (*this)->path() is recursively iterated into
or, if options() & directory_options::skip_permissions_denied != directory_options::none
and an error occurs indicating that permission to access directory (*this)->path() is denied, then directory (*this)->path() is treated as an empty directory and no error is reported .
